title: Charles Loewen
text:
<a href="General">General</a> Sir Charles Falkland Loewen, (17 September 1900 – 17 August 1986) was a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> born and educated soldier who became <a href="Adjutant-General%20to%20the%20Forces">Adjutant-General to the Forces</a> in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>.
Early life and military career.
Educated at the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%20of%20Canada">Royal Military College of Canada</a> in <a href="Kingston%2C%20Ontario">Kingston, Ontario</a>, where he enrolled in 1916, Charles Loewen joined the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> in 1918 where he was <a href="Officer%20%28armed%20forces%29">commissioned</a> as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> into the <a href="Royal%20Field%20Artillery">Royal Field Artillery</a> during the close of the <a href="World%20War%20I">First World War</a> as he was too young for active service with the <a href="Canadian%20Army">Canadian Army</a>. He was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> on 17 March 1920, and to <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> on 17 September 1931.
He was a student at the <a href="Pakistan%20Command%20and%20Staff%20College">Staff College, Quetta</a> in 1933, and was promoted to <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> on 2 July 1937. Promoted to major the following year, he served in <a href="British%20Raj">British India</a> with the local rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a> (from 1 November 1938). Loewen was promoted to brevet lieutenant colonel on 1 July 1939. That same year saw the outbreak of the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a> in Europe, at which time Loewen was serving in England as an instructor at the <a href="Staff%20College%2C%20Camberley">Staff College, Camberley</a>.
Second World War.
Promoted to war substantive lieutenant colonel in 1941, in the <a href="World%20War%20II">Second World War</a> he served as <a href="Commander%2C%20Royal%20Artillery">Commander, Royal Artillery</a> (CRA) in the <a href="55th%20%28West%20Lancashire%29%20Infantry%20Division">55th (West Lancashire) Infantry Division</a>, then <a href="6th%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">6th Infantry Division</a>, then <a href="1st%20Infantry%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">1st Infantry Division</a> and finally <a href="I%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">I Corps</a>. He saw active service during the <a href="Norwegian%20campaign">Norwegian campaign</a> and took part in planning in the <a href="War%20Office">War Office</a>. He was promoted to <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">colonel</a> on 30 June 1943 (seniority from 1 July 1942). In 1943, he drafted Operation Skyscraper to occur on the beaches of Normandy. The plan was shelved as it was thought to need too many resources. It was re-used and re-expanded in <a href="Operation%20Overlord">Operation Overlord</a> back to the original ten divisions - which Skyscraper had recommended in the first place.
He was also involved in the <a href="Italian%20campaign%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Italian campaign</a> where he later served as <a href="General%20officer%20commanding">General Officer Commanding</a> (GOC) of the British 1st Infantry Division from July 1944. As a temporary brigadier by 1944, he was appointed a CBE (Mil.) in the 1944 New Year Honours. He was promoted to the <a href="Acting%20%28rank%29">acting rank</a> of <a href="Major-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major general</a> on 24 July 1944, appointed a Companion of the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a> for distinguished service in Italy on 28 June 1945, appointed a Companion of the Order of the Bath (CB) on 5 July and received a <a href="Mentioned%20in%20dispatches">mention in dispatches</a> on 19 July. He was promoted to temporary major-general on 24 July.
Postwar and retirement.
After the war, Loewen was promoted to the permanent rank of major-general on 6 May 1946 (seniority from 30 August 1944). He took a number of commands including the <a href="6th%20Armoured%20Division%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">6th Armoured Division</a> in 1946, which was later redesignated the <a href="1st%20%28United%20Kingdom%29%20Division">1st Armoured Division</a> and which he led throughout the <a href="Jewish%20insurgency%20in%20Mandatory%20Palestine">Palestine Emergency</a>, and, returning to England, the <a href="50th%20%28Northumbrian%29%20Infantry%20Division">50th (Northumbrian) Infantry Division</a> and Northumbrian District in 1948. He was awarded the U.S. Legion of Merit in the degree of Commander on 14 May 1948. He was appointed General Officer Commanding-in-Chief (GOC-in-C) of <a href="Anti-Aircraft%20Command">Anti-Aircraft Command</a> on 27 May 1950, with a promotion to <a href="Lieutenant-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant-general</a> from the same date. Knighted with the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">KBE</a> in the <a href="1951%20King%27s%20Birthday%20Honours">1951 King's Birthday Honours</a>, he was appointed GOC-in-C of <a href="Western%20Command%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Western Command</a> on 23 April 1953.
He became <a href="Commander-in-chief">Commander-in-Chief</a> (C-in-C) <a href="British%20Far%20East%20Command">Far East Land Forces</a> on 13 October 1953. Appointed a <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">KCB</a> in the <a href="1954%20New%20Year%20Honours">1954 New Year Honours</a>, following his promotion to <a href="General%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">general</a> on 16 April, he went on to be <a href="Adjutant-General%20to%20the%20Forces">Adjutant-General to the Forces</a> in 1956. He retired from the British Army in 1959.
He was <a href="Aide-de-Camp%20General">Aide-de-Camp General</a> to the <a href="Elizabeth%20II%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Queen</a> from 1956 to 1959.
Loewen moved with his wife to be with his sons, Charles Bernard Loewen and John Falkland Loewen, and retired at The Boyne River Mill near to <a href="Mansfield">Mansfield</a>. He was the author of a book entitled "Fly fishing flies".
Honours and legacy.
Loewen, a graduate of the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%20of%20Canada">Royal Military College of Canada</a>, is listed on the Wall of Honour in <a href="Kingston%2C%20Ontario">Kingston, Ontario</a>.
